Aura Wilming
Writer of fiction, blogs and erotica. Frequency in that order. Popularity in reverse.
Apr 15

Diversion

Maria was strangely aware of Jack using her shower. She hated his guts — that feeling was mutual, as shown by the efforts of both to have the other killed. For a while she had thought she succeeded. But then he had shown up and almost died for real. She had ended up saving his life and then let herself be talked into a job — A job she knew was bad news — and as a result she had been robbed at gunpoint, with a very real possibility she now had to get rid of her house and find a new one, because they might know where she lived. She didn’t even have an idea who they were or what they were capable of, but judging by the last 12 hours, moving seemed a good precaution. That pissed her off more than anything. She liked it here. All of it was Jack’s fault. She was seething.

At the same time her mind kept focusing on the fact he was just one wall away from her, naked. In all the detail she really didn’t need to be reminded off. And she didn’t need her body responding to the mental image, either. There was just little she could do about it. The thrill of it all made her horny. She supposed it was the one reason things had worked for as long as they had.

The sound of water running stopped. Maria let out a deep breath. Maybe her mind would return to normal now. A couple of seconds later she heard the door open.

“Do you have anything I can wear?”

She looked up from her laptop screen to see him standing there with just a towel wrapped around him. She silently cursed at him and looked back at the screen. “No. Just wear what you had been wearing.”

“Those ugly ass boxers are four sizes too big for me. Even if I do pull the string tight. Or do you want my trousers to fall off me?”

Maria threw her keys at his head. “Just take the damned car and go get yourself something else.”

“Oh, did I touch a nerve?” Jack grinned, only just dodging the keys. He started putting his ill-fitting clothes on. Maria forced herself not to look. “What’cha doing?” He asked trying to see on her screen.

“Reading the Wikipedia page on Moche culture.”

“The people who made the knife we’re going to steal?”

Maria nodded. “You said Nina might want it for religious reasons? These Moche had a fucked up religion, Jack. They practiced human sacrifice”

“Kali Maa” Jack said dramatically.

“Kali is a Hindi goddess, dumbass. And that whole Indiana Jones scene was fictional. This was real. They were even drinking blood. Listen to this: The Moche may have also held and tortured the victims for several weeks before sacrificing them, with the intent of deliberately drawing blood. Some parts of the victim may have been eaten as well in ritual cannibalism.” She looked at Jack, who was thankfully fully dressed by now. “What do you make of that?”

“South American vampires?”

“Can you be serious for a moment?” Maria said with a heavy sigh.

“But I am serious. Could you tell how old that Nina was? She seemed ageless to me.”

“Vampires don’t exist, Jack,” Maria said flatly. She was already tired of his shit. “Religious fanatics do exist. We’re dealing with someone willing to spend a ridiculous amount of money on a object which only value, as far as we can tell, comes from religious beliefs. A religion we know next to nothing about, except for vicious torture and human sacrifice. Hell, the god is called the Decapitator.” Jack stared at her blankly for a second and then shrugged. Maria rubbed the bridge of her nose with her index finger and thumb. As so often when she tried to talk to Jack, a headache was forming. “There’s people blowing themselves up in the name of a religion which claims to be peaceful. This religion thrives on violence. Who knows what someone would do in its name. Doesn’t that bother you at all?”

“You worry too much,” Jack said soothingly and petted Maria on her head. For some reason she restrained herself from breaking all the bones in his hand. “We’re going to grab that knife and collect our money, and that will be that. If they want to slice and eat someone after that, it’s none of our business.” He made his way towards the front door, spinning the car keys around his finger.

“Lets see you be this nonchalant when you find out they put you on the menu.”

“That’s why I wanted you on this job with me, my sweet wife,” Jack said, looking over his shoulder. “If anyone is going to be slicing me up, I know it will be you. I won’t be long.”

Maria shook her head, smiling despite herself. “You’re incorrigible,” she said softly to the closing door. She listened to the sounds of car engine start up and slowly growing dimmer as Jack drove down the street. When she was certain he was gone, she closed the laptop and got up. She needed a long, cold shower.

She heard the front door open and close when the skin on her fingertips had already become pruney. She turned off the water and grabbed her towel. In the other room it sounded like Jack was searching for something. Maria wrapped the towel around herself holding it up with her left hand while she grabbed the door knob with her right. “Jack? Did you find a what you needed?” she asked loudly. She opened the door and stepped into the living room.

She stopped dead in her tracks as she found herself looking down the barrel of a gun for the second time in an afternoon. Holding the gun was not Jack, but the large man who had been following them in the beige car.

“No Misses Maria,” the man said emotionless, “I did not find what I was looking for. Maybe you can help me.”

Maria stood staring at the man, shocked. Even though she had expected him to come looking for Jack and her again, she had not thought he would be so quick about it. Her mind was racing. She caught a shadow in the window in her peripheral vision. Was that Jack, or some of the locals the man had hired? She needed to stall for time.

“What sort of game is your boss playing?” she asked, trying to sound as outraged as possible. “We said we would help her.”

The man laughed. “Miss Nina might think she’s my boss, but she’s not. I would never work for such a woman.” As he spoke his lip pulled up on one side. Maria knew the expression well; pure contempt. This could get ugly fast.

“If you’re looking for the money, I don’t have it. Jack took it with him.” She dared to look quickly at the window next to the door. If there was someone outside, they were good at staying hidden. Not the locals, she decided. If it was Jack out there, she hoped he would remember about her gun under the drivers seat in the car.

The man sighed regretfully. “I had hoped to dissuade you from stealing the tumi by taking your reward. It would have been nice to avoid bloodshed. It is unfortunate that you are so smart.” He pulled back on the hammer of his revolver. “Your husband made it very clear that his one condition for doing this job, is you”

Maria instinctively put her hands up, palms out. By letting go of her towel, it dropped to the ground. As set as the man had seemed on shooting her, being faced with a naked woman was distracting enough to stare for a moment and not to pull the trigger.

Suddenly a couple of loud bangs sounded from the other side of the front door. The man spun around quickly and shot a bullet through the door. The bangs continued. A small wisp of smoke and some shreds of red paper came into the room from under the door.

“What…?”

The moment of confusion gave Jack enough time to sprint through the back door and press the barrel of Maria’s gun to the back of the man’s head. “Drop it!” he commanded.

The man raised his hands slowly, his revolver tumbling from his hands. Maria snatched it up as quick as she could and clubbed the man hard on the head as she straightened up. The man’s eyes rolled back into his head before falling sideways to the ground.

“Nice diversion,” Maria had to admit to Jack. She emptied the drum of the revolver to make sure the gun was unloaded.

“Likewise,” Jack replied slightly breathless.

Maria looked his way to see him stare at her. Annoyed, she picked up the towel to cover herself again. “How do you even know a word like likewise?”

“What, do you think I’m twelve?” Jack said. Maria simply raised her eyebrows in reply. “I read,” Jack added defensive.

“Yes, but you also buy firecrackers when you go into town.” Maria countered with a smirk.

“Hey, those firecrackers saved your pretty ass!” Jack exclaimed and sniffed indignantly at her. “And they weren’t to play with. I remember you using firecrackers to make a device to disable a truck once. I thought they would come in handy for the job.”

“You’re right. I’m sorry,” Maria smiled, “And thank you. You did save my ass.”

“Makes us even,” Jack said with a dismissive gesture. “Do you have anything to tie this guy up?”

“There should be a roll of duct tape under the sink”

“Yes?” Maria heard Nina say over the phone. “It’s Maria. We need to talk,” she said.

“Is there a problem?”

“We were robbed at gunpoint.”

“Are you all right?” Nina asked. The woman was either a superb voice actor, or she was genuinely concerned by Maria’s revelation. “Is Jack okay?”

“Jack and I are fine.”

“What about Juju?”

“Tall, dark and ugly, who’s been following us around all day?” Maria asked.

“Yes,” Nina replied, “I ordered him to keep an eye on you, for your safety.”

“Yeah, about that…” Maria turned to look at the man strapped to a kitchen chair with duct tape and gagged with a sock. “…Funny story…”
